title: 1974년 United States v. Leonard B. Ricketson 사건
summary: 미국 USA, Federal 법원 판결 사건. 사건명: United States v. Leonard B. Ricketson. 판결일: 1974-10-29. 법원: Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit.
description:
## 사건 정보

**사건명**: UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee, v. Leonard B. RICKETSON, Defendant-Appellant
**판결일**: 1974-10-29
**법원**: Court of Appeals for the Seventh Circuit
**관할**: USA, Federal

**판사**: Cummings, Fairchild, Jame-Son

## 변호인

George E. Faber, Chicago, Ill., for defendant-appellant., James R. Thompson, U. S. Atty., Gary L. Starkman, Asst. U. S. Atty., Chicago, Ill., for plaintiff-appellee.

## 인용

- 498 F.2d 367

## 판결문 요약

498 F.2d 367
    UNITED STATES of America, Plaintiff-Appellee,v.Leonard B. RICKETSON, Defendant-Appellant.
    No. 73-1618.
    United States Court of Appeals, Seventh Circuit.
    Heard Feb. 26, 1974.Decided May 30, 1974, Certiorari Denied Oct. 29, 1974, See95 S.Ct. 227.
    
      George E. Faber, Chicago, Ill., for defendant-appellant.
      James R. Thompson, U.S. Atty., Gary L. Starkman, Asst. U.S. Atty., Chicago, Ill., for plaintiff-appellee.
      Before FAIRCHILD and CUMMINGS, Circuit Judges, and JAMESON, /0/ Senior District Judge.
      CUMMINGS, Circuit Judge.
    
    
      1
      In February 1972, a 3-count indictment was returned against defendant and Leo Rugendorf, Francis Hohimer and Colin Green.  The charges livolved a jewelry theft that took place in Indianapolis, Indiana, on June 16, 1967.  The first count charged the four defendants with a conspiracy to transport in interstate commerce jewelry worth more than $5,000, and to receive it and sell it-- all in violation of 18 U.S.C. 371, the general conspiracy statute.  Count II charged them with transporting the jewelry from Indianapolis to Chicago in violation of 18 U.S.C. 2 and 2314.  The final count charged that defendant Rugendorf received the same jewelry in interstate commerce, knowing it to have been stolen, in violation of 18 U.S.C. 2 and 2315.  Sections 2314 and 2315 forbid the transportation and sale or receipt of stolen goods with a value of $5,000 or more; Section 2 is the general aiding and abett...
